value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Further, <del>this</del> he has given currency to much more</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>than any other writer,</del> that everyone can <del>find</del> [make? small?] [hug?]</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">himself in 
            <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William"><choice>
              <sic>Sh<hi rend="superscript">re</hi></sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></rs> <del>The scholars</del> <del>We have therefore</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>self no</del> <del>the reader can always extract the</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>very words that fit himself.</del> In other</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>books there is</del> <del>this</del> It is for this reason</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>that</del> the critic <del>paits his o</del> is always</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>accenting the</del> can always find in 
            <choice>
              <sic>Sh<hi rend="superscript">re</hi></sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>a</del> something that only he can find – his own</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">idiosyncrasies. Hence the autobiographical</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">element in             
            <choice>
              <sic>Sh.</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice> criticism: Each of their explorers</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">is <del>drawn</del> seems for a moment to sum up, &</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">then is consumed, & the light forms from behind him:</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">this effort which it leaves 
            <choice>
              <sic>Sh<hi rend="superscript">re</hi></sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice> always
          </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">undiscivered, in the sense that [later?] writers are</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">summed up because there are such obvious</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">limits to their power. But it means that</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Sh<hi rend="superscript">re</hi></sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice> is always alive. <del>It is useless to fight</del>
          </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>[survived?] him s</del> <del>At</del> <del>The</del> <del>And although</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>the appetite of the reader is always capacious:</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he is not, as so many writers are, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He does not, as so many writers do, feed</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">momentary appetites & all readers who</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">are themselves writers, feel <del>at</del> inexplicable</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">hunger, for certain styles, for certain forms.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Sh<hi rend="superscript">re</hi></sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare's</corr>
            </choice> styles are so innumerable that he never
          </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">lowers <del>as to</del> to clear up any particular points</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>any</del> <del>the</del> He can as [soon?] be read, when the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">ink has gone dry on the pen, to restore language</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He can give the general sense of speed.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But the style & the [scope?] make him</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">unsuitable, unless, for the writer as a model.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Then</l>
